top_comment.text:
I agree. Same sex couples should be allowed to marry. It in no way bothers 
anyone personally. It's not like if they marry, straight couples will 
suddenly develop some sort of sickness or disease. It has no effect on 
anybody.

However... the church has the right to say they don't believe in same-sex 
marriage. Freedom of expression, right? To the religious, it is morally 
wrong, and that's ok. If Scientoligists can say we are aliens (or whatever 
nutty thing they believe in) then Christians can say they don't believe in 
gay marriage. Just like atheists can say they don't believe in God. 

But... the church should not be allowed to try and force other people to 
comply with their specific beliefs. Laws should not be passed according to 
a religion's views or ideals. Simply because we don't all believe in the 
same thing. Also, homosexuals should not sue and force a religious person 
to perform a wedding ceremony or bake a cake for them, making them go 
against their beliefs. Imagine that you are on a diet... and I force you to 
eat a greasy burger, simply because I am *not* on a diet. Or imagine that 
you get forced on a diet simply because *I'm*  on a diet. It works both 
ways with religion and homosexuality.

I think that a lot of of people who preach tolerance... on both sides of 
the spectrum... need to practice tolerance themselves. I will respect that 
you are on a diet, if you respect that I want to eat a greasy burger. 

To the religious, I say this: Don't condemn a person to hell simply because 
they don't share your beliefs. You are not a judge. You will be judged in 
the end by the Almighty. Spread the word of God, and the word of God is 
*love*. Don't mistreat or condemn or oppress homosexuals. Love them. They 
are your neighbors. And God said *Love thy neighbor*. Practice what you 
preach instead of being judgmental hypocrites.

Those who don't believe in any religion, I say this: You don't have to 
agree with them. You don't have to comply with their rules. But too many 
times I have seen religious people, even the good ones, get bashed and 
ridiculed by their beliefs. There are good people within religions. Not 
everyone is a crazy fanatic who condemns everyone to hell. Respect each 
other. We must all practice being a little more civilized to one another. 
Ridiculing a person for their beliefs is no better than damning someone to 
hell for their sexuality. ﻿

"if there had been far more homosexuals"

One reason why virtually every other species on this planet is under threat 
and why so many children live such short, miserable lives is that there are 
simply *too many humans*, so obviously if a greater percentage had been 
homosexual, there would be fewer humans and that would be a good thing.

Say there were only 3 billion humans on the planet, that would be a 
sustainable amount, but by the end of this century, even without any 
increase in family size, there will be 11 billion people on the planet.

extinct by the time that happens, though.

ideology used to dominate. First, in country music - a genre of music that

support of gay marriages. Now you have the world of wrestling - usually a

against gays. As history has demonstrated countless times on other 
subjects, religious conservatives are on the losing side of history.﻿

comments.text:
+Janusha
Actually, no. There are a shit ton of people that get married by a justice 
of the peace, who usually aren't affiliated with any religious institution 
(even though they might be religious themselves). My step dad is one and 
he's presided over plenty of ceremonies. Most were married on our B&B 
property, not anywhere near a church. I'm not aware of any that were held 
in a church that he officiated, actually. Also, several of said ceremonies 
were same-sex marriages -- he's a christian and doesn't agree with 
homosexuality, but he's a decent man and does his job without making them 
feel guilt about who they are and the person they've chosen to love. Many 
other people just go to their town hall to have a marriage certificate 
drawn up and processed through because they don't want all the fuss of a 
ceremony.

And when the hell is *christmas* celebrated in a church? Last time I 
checked it was a ritual/ceremony that involved spending time with your 
family as well as giving and receiving gifts. Sure, people talk about it 
being Jesus's birthday (which we aren't even sure of, because the bible 
doesn't seem to point to that date anyway) and shit, but that's not what 
it's about. It's about showing goodwill to fellow humans, which is 
wonderful.

Funerals... yes, typically done by a religious person, but only because 
they offer a sense of comfort about there being an afterlife. The actual 
ritual is a way for those that are grieving to come to terms with the 
reality and gather together to give each other support in a terrible time. 
It is far less a religious ceremony than one of humans supporting other 
humans. It's all about people coming up and talking about their memories 
with the deceased, honoring their life and the times they had together. It 
has nothing to do with god -- or, rather, it shouldn't / doesn't need to be.

comments.text:
What do we have left? You're seriously attempting to make that into a point?
*MARRIAGE WAS NOT A CONCEPT INVENTED BY CHRISTIANS!*
I'm sick and fucking tired of hearing this 'argument'. The idea of a union 
between a woman and a man has been around since before recorded history and 
was typically massively polygamist for any man that had the luxury (which, 
by the way, was recorded many times in the handful of 'precious', bronze 
age, fear-mongering, 'holy' texts that so many now rely on for 'wisdom' 
when the people that wrote them knew essentially nothing that we know of 
logic and science). It was also done almost exclusively for political or 
economic power, even perhaps just further influence and always had the end 
goal of procreation. The trend towards monogamy is only something that was 
pushed into marriage through the catholic church in the span between the 
6th and 9th centuries and even then only really for Europeans -- so in the 
case of monogamous marriage being an agenda that was pushed by christians 
later? Yes. It's only been for about 250 years that we've been entertaining 
this idea of a marriage being for love, and it's wonderful that now that's 
what it's [supposed to be] about. If you are banning someone from marriage, 
you are banning them from an expression of loyalty and love to another 
human being. It's just unnecessary religious bullshit; claiming rights to a 
ceremony that it did not invent just to attempt to keep the status quo... 
because it's made painfully clear that you have to drag them kicking and 
screaming to any point of change.

The point is, current marriage is essentially secular. To be officially 
married is to have a marriage certificate -- which the church does not have 
any say in -- that places you in a relationship with another human being 
that is seen as a special relationship with tax breaks as well as a 
different IRS status. *That's it.* What religious folks get so up in arms 
about is the *ceremony*, which is completely unnecessary but we still do 
it. It also doesn't have to be done by a priest; a justice of the peace is 
able to do it and they are typical unaffiliated (at least by their job) 
with religions. I've never understood why the LGBT community doesn't just 
boycott the churches; they don't need them to keep their faith (as some are 
christian and still do wish to worship, even if their companions condemn 
them for being themselves). Despite that perfectly rational alternative, 
the massive *stink* that religious people raise about this... it's just 
completely ridiculous, like its book.

Why do gays want to be married? Maybe because they love one another and 
want to pledge that. On one hand you call marriage "a holy union between 
man and woman" -- then you turn right around and say "it's just a word". If 
you can't see the hypocrisy in that alone... you had the sense beaten out 
of you as a child.

government can and does override god's law (whatever that law happens to be

authority in favor of their god's, as you point out, but in doing so they 
will face the inescapable consequences of their dissent.  As I said, you

+Keir Campbell Your point that a group would consider god to be a greater 
authority than government is immaterial, because the government can and 
will override that authority if it has a vested interest in doing so (i.e. 
to prevent discrimination against protected classes, or to ensure the 
safety of it's citizens).

What's particularly interesting is that you yourself  speak out against 
actions that would stem from certain sincerely held beliefs (such as 
persecution of homosexuals), because they do not comport with your 
own. Apparently, you do agree then that you in fact do NOT have the right 
to act upon all religious beliefs - only those that don't do damage to 
society.

Also, note that I am making a very important distinction between beliefs 
and actions, and that one should be tolerant through actions, not through 
personal thoughts. The government cannot act as thought police and force 
individuals to accept anyone. However, the government can certainly hold 
accountable any individual that acts on their beliefs, stemming from 
intolerance, in a way that is detrimental to certain citizens or to society 
as a whole.

loss of tax exemption which you said you still have to consider.

tell you what you can and cannot practice. Some might, for instance,

belief, they are not permitted to act upon that belief in any way, 
regardless of whether they feel that their "gods" allowed or even mandated 
such actions. 

Note that the actual interpretation of how to deal with talmudic laws or 
whether they apply to modern society is wholly irrelevant. There is no test 
for the accuracy of one's personal beliefs and whether they even conform to 
scripture - it is only required that they are sincerely-held, and the 
belief holders' imaginations can run wild and free. 

Furthermore, I presented to you a conditional statement - I said that 
churches should be mandated to perform gay/lesbian weddings because of 
their tax-exemption status, which was instituted specifically because 
churches offer valuable community service. If they start doing anything 
that would go against tolerance or create division within communities, then

to desire a selection, women have evolved to desire a serious one on one.

Man can have his offspring growing in dozens of women
Women can only grow one man's seed, every year (or so).
Nature shows always have the Alpha males fighting to impregnate ALL the 
females
It's never a Lion fighting so he can cop off with a single female and, 
after 3 months of good sex and excitement, spend the rest of his life 
wondering why he got a mortgage with this dull fucking bitch!!!

LOVE - IT's a type of insanity - and it's temporary.
BUT while it's really peaking (first few months) you do insane things, like 
take on staggering amounts of joint debt.
Once the love (chemical hormonal imbalance) calms down, you can't afford to 
keep all the stuff without her half of the cash paying for it...
So you try and forget how boring it is....

Monogamy is biologically unsustainable in males below the age of 76.
